titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Nelson Sullivan Video Collection
1976 - 1989
MSS 357
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Cristina Vignone, 2013

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-10-02T17:19-0400

did.abstract: Nelson Sullivan (1948-1989) was a video artist who documented downtown New York City in the 1980s. The Nelson Sullivan Video Collection contains videorecordings of the city's art world and LGBT community as well as performances in clubs, house parties, and interactions with Sullivan's friends from 1976-1989.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The archivist preserved the original order of the video collection as donated by the estate of Nelson Sullivan. The series of videorecordings have not been chronologically or thematically rearranged.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: Nelson Sullivan (1948-1989) was a video artist who documented downtown New York City in the 1980s. Originally from South Carolina, Sullivan moved to Manhattan in the 1970s and began filming the city's art world and gay scene. He captured John Sex, Sylvia Miles, RuPaul, and other performers at downtown bars and nightclubs including Danceteria, the Limelight, Palladium, and the Pyramid Club. Sullivan also chronicled house parties at his apartment at 5 Ninth Avenue in the Meatpacking District, gallery openings, park and street festivals, conversations with taxi drivers, and the ruminations of his friends including fashion designer Alexis Del Lago and journalist Michael Musto on film. He recorded almost 2,000 hours of tape, at first using a VHS-loading camera and later an 8mm video camera. Sullivan's filmmaking is recognizable for its point of view transitions and its stream-of-consciousness narration. He also often pointed a wide-angle lens at his own face while filming to record his commentary on the people, performances, or events that he captured. Sullivan made films up until his death from a heart attack on July 4, 1989.

p.extref: John Sanchez Interview with Dick Richards about Nelson Sullivan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Nelson Sullivan Video Collection is a collection of videorecordings made by video artist Nelson Sullivan (1948-1989). The collection consists of videotapes of the city's art world and LGBT community as well as performances in clubs, house parties, and interactions with Sullivan's friends. The videos cover the period 1976-1989.
The collection is comprised of 1 series:
Series I: Videorecordings contains 8 boxes of videorecordings made by Nelson Sullivan.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.
Some audiovisual items have not been preserved and therefore are currently unavailable to researchers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Nelson Sullivan Video Collection; MSS 357; unique identification number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

odd.head: Provenance
odd.p: The Nelson Sullivan Video Collection was donated to Fales Library by the estate of Nelson Sullivan, overseen by Dick Richards, David Goldman, and Robert Coddington operating collectively as the 5 Ninth Avenue Project, in September 2012.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at Fales Library and Special Collections

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.
